Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a High-Power Adaptive Phased Fiber-Array Laser System

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The high-power laser systems currently used in various industries (automotive, aerospace, defense, nuclear and fusion energy, gas/oil, etc.) suffer from a lack of agile/intelligent control of high-power laser beam characteristics. They use the brute force of kW-class laser power to melt or evaporate materials without real-time process monitoring and intelligent feedback control. With the increasing demand for processing and joining a variety of novel material types and emerging development of additive manufacturing techniques, the high-power laser energy source technology must meet stricter fit-form-function requirements for excellent beam quality and precise spatial and temporal control of energy flux. This project is focused on development of a high-energy continuous wave (CW) Adaptive Phased Fiber-Array (APFA) laser system that is designed to fulfill these requirements, leading to yet unexplored opportunities for significant advances in laser material processing. Multi-kW power laser systems with excellent beam quality and adaptive beam control capabilities are also required in diverse, directed energy applications, such as long-distance battery recharging and optical power transfer, remote demolition of infrastructure elements in a contaminated area, future photon-assisted propulsion of spacecraft, and distant interrogation of asteroids.

Emerging from recent technology breakthroughs in high-power fiber-lasers and adaptive beam control, the APFA laser instrument includes: (a) a multi-kW CW laser energy source comprised of a seven-channel high-power fiber amplifier system, (b) a high-power adaptive fiber-array laser head with an advanced water-cooling system, (c) integrated sensors for adaptive mitigation of mechanical jitter and optical aberrations resulting from laser beam interaction with the material, and (d) a hybrid (feedback/programmable) control system for real-time manipulation of the high-power energy flux spatial and temporal characteristics. The proposed instrumentation combines in a novel single laser energy source the most highly desired characteristics and capabilities in laser material processing and directed energy applications including: excellent (M^2<1.15) beam quality at 10 kW power level, precise (submicron accuracy) electronic beam pointing and stabilization, wide-range focal spot steering and adaptive refocusing, adaptive compensation for mechanical jitter and heat-induced aberrations, programmable control of laser beam polarization, spatial and temporal coherence, and intelligent control of energy flux spatial distribution. The APFA laser energy source will substantially broaden research and provide an excellent opportunity for education and training in the burgeoning areas of fiber-laser technology, laser material processing and manufacturing, and advanced control, enhancing careers in these multiple scientific fields. The availability of the new laser system to both industrial researchers and University programs also helps the local area economy in its transitioning to high-tech industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The high-power laser systems currently used for applications such as material processing (welding, drilling, cutting, scribing, surface texturing, additive manufacturing, etc.) in various industries (automotive, aerospace, defense, nuclear and fusion energy, gas/oil, etc.) suffer from a lack of agile/intelligent control of high-power laser beam characteristics. They use the brute force of the laser to heat, melt and/or evaporate materials without real-time process monitoring and intelligent feedback, or programmable control of beam characteristics. The 6.5 kW Adaptive Phased Fiber-Array (APFA) laser system, developed under the NSF Major Research Instrumentation program, with additional support by the State of Ohio, the University of Dayton, and industrial partner Optonicus/II-VI Inc. addresses the need for a fundamentally new continuous-wave multi-kilowatt laser source with multiple control opportunities for intelligent, adaptive laser beam delivery to a work piece.

The developed APFA system can be divided into three major subsystems: low-power fiber optics part, high-power amplifier array, free-space optical part with laser head, plus supporting equipment. The low-power fiber-optics part comprises a linewidth-broadened seed fiber laser, a splitter dividing the seed laser light into seven channels, and fiber-based control elements for polarization, phase, and group delay for each channel. This subsystem contains also custom micro-processor-based control electronics and supervising control computers. The high-power amplifier array consists of seven energy efficient commercial off-the-shelf fiber laser amplifiers with up to 1 kW output, a power supply with power distribution system, and a control interface. The free-space optics part begins with the laser head, an array of seven fiber collimators, where custom two-axis piezoelectric actuators allow one of the lenses in each collimator's optical system to be repositioned laterally, thus enabling fine pointing of each of the seven beams. The beams emerging from the laser head are directed through two 45° dielectric mirrors to a lens, which covers the full aperture of the array and focuses the seven beams onto the surface of the work piece. Leakage light from two dielectric mirrors, in conjunction with appropriate sensor setups, are used to provide feedback signals for polarization, phase, and group delay control. Fine pointing of the beams is used to dynamically control the laser hit-spot locations on the work piece, allowing for generation of different beam formations ranging from perfectly overlapping hit spots (to achieve maximum irradiance) to various spatial distributions optimized for the specific applications. The operation of the APFA system is supported by equipment of the University of Dayton's high power laser facility, which includes a water cooling system with chillers, high-power laser enclosures, a clean room, and an access control system.

The APFA laser system is a game-changing intelligent energy source that enables the generation of high-power laser beams at a work piece surface with a wide variety of controllable spatio-temporal characteristics. It can be used for various research areas including advanced material processing, scale-modeling of planetary defense from asteroids with directed energy, remote energy transfer and battery powering, and high-energy laser physics. The APFA laser system provides new capabilities for both research and education in the emerging areas of high-power laser systems, control of complex systems, and physics of high-energy laser beam interaction with metallic materials. The APFA high-power laser system broadens the research capacities of faculty members, post-docs, and students at the University of Dayton and other local universities. It provides an excellent opportunity for training of students in the burgeoning areas of fiber-laser technology, advanced control, laser material processing and manufacturing, and thus enhance careers in these multiple scientific fields. The availability of the new laser system to both industrial researchers and University programs will support the transition of the traditional manufacturing industry of the US Midwest and Northeast to 21st-century material processing technology and knowledge-based manufacturing.
